pros: As a small college, you get to know the rest of the college community well. It's easy to build good collegial relationships with staff from other departments. Many of the students are kind and ambitious - you see the fruits of your labor in the great work they do. There are a lot of opportunities for community engagement outside of your job.
cons: As a small college, staff wear many hats and you'll likely get pulled in to do work not related to your job. Considering the amount of work needed to successfully do your job and provide the expected top-notch customer service, the pay should be higher.

job_title: Peer Tutor for the Center for Writing and Speaking in Decatur, GA
pros: Agnes Scott College is dedicated to helping their students gain necessary and helpful learning experiences in various departments on campus. I worked in Technology Production Services as a student assistant for two years and with the Center for Writing and Speaking as a tutor, and have been fortunate to learn how to work in a team oriented environment and provide good customer service. I really enjoyed working at Agnes because my coworkers as well as management were fair and consistent in scheduling hours, so maintaining a good work/school balance was very achievable. While there was no room for student workers to advance in the departments they work for, in some instances, the work experience gained is completely applicable to real world jobs. My current employer recruits through Agnes Scott, so there are many opportunities for students to find work outside of campus as well.
cons: The pay is low. Even though I had excellent work experiences I feel that I did an large amount of work for very little pay. I worked for minimum wage as well as about a dollar above minimum wage hourly for a maximum of 30 hours weekly. There also is no ability for advancement in student jobs or pay raises, which is due to the College's recent budgeting decreases.

review_title: Laid-Back with Great Benefits, but Low Pay and Little Room for Promotion
pros: Agnes Scott College is extraordinarily supportive of a work-life balance.  When employees need to take time off from work, the college is generous and understanding.  Also, ASC provides great compensation and benefits.  Staff members who work 35 hours a week or more, for 12 months, are eligible for all benefits.  Full-time or half-time employees who complete at least 1,000 continuous work hours each year are eligible for and are required to participate in the College's 403(b) Defined Contribution Retirement Plan. Participants have an option of contributing 5 percent of their salary to this fund with Agnes Scott College contributing 10 percent, or they may contribute 3.5 percent with Agnes Scott contributing 7 percent.  In both cases, the College is contributing to the retirement plans on a 2-for-1 basis.
cons: If you enjoy a fast-paced workplace, you will not find it at Agnes Scott.  ASC is a laid-back work environment.  Hard working employees are not valued at this college as much as they might be in other environments.  Also, the pay at Agnes Scott is relatively low.

pros: great cafeteria food with $3 lunch for all staff and faculty, low parking fees compared to other colleges, great location, sense of community, blue jean friday, friendly atmosphere, safe campus
cons: The college is behind the times in some areas, limited or no wifi, lack of office space in many departments, deferred maintenance in a lot of buildings

pros:
Agnes Scott has a surprisingly diverse student body considering where it came from and its reputation. No one ethnicity is dominant-- 34% black, 33% white, 9% hispanic; 6% asian (writing in fall of 2020). There are four black woman vice presidents in the organization, including a vp of equity and diversity. There are conversations about race all the time, and not simply because it's trendy rn. A history tradition of engagement with and communicaiton about social and intellectual challenges sets this place apart, and there is a STRONG sense of community around this.

The faculty and staff are genuinely trans and queer friendly. Everyone is attentative to pronouns. 

The school is also attentive to students in need of accomodations.

I love working here because it's a real community--living in a dynamic time, and responding as it can. It ain't perfect, but it's supportive.

It's one block from a trendy indy area with great food, independent stored, coffee shops and a center plaza for entertainment. It's 6 miles from downtown Atlanta, it's two blocks from the mass transit.
cons:
It's an institution, and like any other institution, change is hard and slow. There is a wide sense of POC feeling like the college talks about diversity as a "plug" and doesn't really do the work necessary for inclusion. As a faculty member I think this is one of those things that is true and untrue at the same time. There is no doubt that there is a huge effort toward making inclusion feel real and effective, and also, cultural change is slow. In a school, every four years the students sift through, so change may not be apparent to new students. No doubt too, that it is an HWC (historiically white), and has HWC traditions. (ie feels white). 

Another place wider cultural issues appear are in political representation--conservative students, and christian students have voiced that they feel unheard and unseen, and that it isn't socially acceptiable for them to have their views.
